name: Beryllium
origin_of_name: Beryl, a mineral (ultimately from the name ofBelurin southern India)[4]

name: Sodium
origin_of_name: Coined byHumphry Davywho first isolated it, from Englishsoda(specificallycaustic soda), via Italian from Arabicṣudāʕ'headache'·Symbol Na is derived fromNeo-Latinnatrium, coined from GermanNatron, 'natron'

name: Potassium
origin_of_name: Neo-Latinpotassa, 'potash', itself frompotandash·Symbol K is derived from Neo-Latinkalium, from German

name: Titanium
origin_of_name: Titans, the sons of the earth goddess of Greek mythology

name: Vanadium
origin_of_name: Vanadis, anOld Norsename for the Scandinavian goddessFreyja

name: Iron
origin_of_name: English, fromProto-Celtic*īsarnom('iron'), from a root meaning 'blood'·Symbol Fe is derived from Latinferrum

name: Nickel
origin_of_name: Nickel, a mischievousspriteof German miner mythology

name: Copper
origin_of_name: English, from Latincuprum, from Ancient GreekKýpros'Cyprus'

name: Zinc
origin_of_name: Most likely from GermanZinke, 'prong' or 'tooth', though some suggestPersiansang, 'stone'

name: Arsenic
origin_of_name: Middle English, fromMiddle Frencharsenic, from Greekarsenikón'yellow arsenic' (influenced byarsenikós, 'masculine' or 'virile'), from aWest Asianwanderwordultimately fromOld Iranian*zarniya-ka, 'golden'

name: Strontium
origin_of_name: Strontian, a village inScotland, where it was found

name: Yttrium
origin_of_name: Ytterby,Sweden, where it was found; see alsoterbium,erbium,ytterbium

name: Niobium
origin_of_name: Niobe, daughter of kingTantalusfrom Greek mythology; see alsotantalum

name: Molybdenum
origin_of_name: Greekmolýbdaina, 'piece oflead', frommólybdos, 'lead', due to confusion with lead oregalena(PbS)

name: Palladium
origin_of_name: Pallas, an asteroid, considered a planet at the time

name: Silver
origin_of_name: English, from a common Germanic root·Symbol Ag is derived from Latinargentum

name: Cadmium
origin_of_name: Neo-Latincadmia, 'calamine', from KingKadmos, legendary founder of Thebes

name: Indium
origin_of_name: Latinindicum, 'indigo', the blue colour found in its spectrum

name: Tin
origin_of_name: English, from a common Germanic root·Symbol Sn is derived from Latinstannum

name: Antimony
origin_of_name: Latinantimonium,the origin of whichis uncertain:folk etymologiessuggest it is derived from Greekantí('against') +mónos('alone'), orOld Frenchanti-moine, 'Monk's bane', but it could plausibly be from or related to Arabicʾiṯmid, 'antimony', reformatted as a Latin word·Symbol Sb is derived from Latinstibium'stibnite'

name: Cerium
origin_of_name: Ceres, a dwarf planet, considered a planet at the time

name: Promethium
origin_of_name: Prometheus, a figure in Greek mythology

name: Samarium
origin_of_name: Samarskite, a mineral named afterV. Samarsky-Bykhovets, Russian mine official

name: Gadolinium
origin_of_name: Gadolinite, a mineral named afterJohan Gadolin, Finnish chemist, physicist and mineralogist

name: Terbium
origin_of_name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see alsoyttrium,erbium,ytterbium

name: Erbium
origin_of_name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see alsoyttrium,terbium,ytterbium

name: Thulium
origin_of_name: Thule, the ancient name for an unclear northern location

name: Ytterbium
origin_of_name: Ytterby, Sweden, where it was found; see alsoyttrium,terbium,erbium

name: Tantalum
origin_of_name: KingTantalus, father of Niobe from Greek mythology; see alsoniobium

name: Tungsten
origin_of_name: Swedishtungsten, 'heavy stone'·Symbol W is fromWolfram, originally fromMiddle High Germanwolf-rahm'wolf's foam' describing the mineralwolframite[5]

name: Iridium
origin_of_name: Iris, the Greek goddess of the rainbow

name: Gold
origin_of_name: English, from the same Proto-Indo-European root as 'yellow'·Symbol Au is derived from Latinaurum

name: Mercury
origin_of_name: Mercury, Roman god of commerce, communication, and luck, known for his speed and mobility·Symbol Hg is derived from its Latin namehydrargyrum, from Greekhydrárgyros, 'water-silver'

name: Lead
origin_of_name: English, fromProto-Celtic*ɸloudom, from a root meaning 'flow'·Symbol Pb is derived from Latinplumbum

name: Bismuth
origin_of_name: GermanWismut, via Latin and Arabic from Greekpsimúthion, 'white lead'

name: Polonium
origin_of_name: LatinPolonia, 'Poland', home country ofMarie Curie, who discovered it

name: Astatine
origin_of_name: Greekástatos, 'unstable', alluding to its lack of stable isotopes

name: Radon
origin_of_name: Radium emanation, originally the name of theisotoperadon-222

name: Francium
origin_of_name: France, home country of discovererMarguerite Perey

name: Radium
origin_of_name: Coined in French by discovererMarie Curie, from Latinradius, 'ray'

name: Thorium
origin_of_name: Thor, the Scandinavian god of thunder

name: Protactinium
origin_of_name: English prefixproto-(from Greekprôtos, 'first, before') +actinium, since actinium is produced through the radioactive decay of protactinium

name: Uranium
origin_of_name: Uranus, the seventh planet in the Solar System

name: Neptunium
origin_of_name: Neptune, the eighth planet in the Solar System

name: Plutonium
origin_of_name: Pluto, a dwarf planet in the Solar System, considered a planet at the time

name: Americium
origin_of_name: The Americas, where the element was first synthesised, by analogy with itshomologue§ europium

name: Curium
origin_of_name: Pierre CurieandMarie Curie, French physicists and chemists

name: Berkelium
origin_of_name: Berkeley, California, where the element was first synthesised

name: Californium
origin_of_name: California, where the element was first synthesised in theLBNLlaboratory

name: Mendelevium
origin_of_name: Dmitri Mendeleev, Russian chemist who proposed theperiodic table

name: Nobelium
origin_of_name: Alfred Nobel, Swedish chemist and engineer

name: Rutherfordium
origin_of_name: Ernest Rutherford, chemist and physicist from New Zealand

name: Dubnium
origin_of_name: Dubna, Russia, where the element was discovered in theJINRlaboratory

name: Darmstadtium
origin_of_name: Darmstadt, Germany, where the element was first synthesised in theGSIlaboratories

name: Nihonium
origin_of_name: JapaneseNihon, 'Japan', where the element was first synthesised in theRikenlaboratories

name: Flerovium
origin_of_name: Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions, part ofJINR, where the element was synthesised; itself named afterGeorgy Flyorov, Russian physicist

name: Moscovium
origin_of_name: Moscow, Russia, where the element was first synthesised in theJINRlaboratories

name: Tennessine
origin_of_name: Tennessee, United States, whereOak Ridge National Laboratoryis located
